subject: Re: [junit] Re: Change generic signature of assert that
msgSnippet: ... Because the wildcard bounds are the wrong way round.  Matcher makes sense, Matcher does not. Consider the following silly
messageBody:
2009/5/22 yme0987654321 <yme0987654321@...>:
> I'm curious if you know of a reason that
>
> public static <T> void assertThat(T actual, Matcher<? extends T> matcher)
>
> is wrong. Does it break something that you know of?


Because the wildcard bounds are the wrong way round. Matcher<? super
T> makes sense, Matcher<? extends T> does not.

Consider the following silly inheritance hierarchy:

Object <- Fruit <- {Banana, Apple}

A Matcher<Fruit> represents some property of the Fruit type that
applies to *all* fruit. I should be able to use it to match against
both Bananas and Apples. In that case, T is bound to Banana, Fruit is
a supertype of Banana, so the matcher satisfies the wildcard Matcher<?
super Banana>.

If I have a Fruit reference, I don't know what kind of Fruit it points
to. If the matcher wildcard was <? extends T> it would allow me pass
the fruit to a Matcher<Apple> even when the fruit was actually a
Banana. If I know a-priori that the Fruit really is an Apple, it is
good practice to explicitly downcast the reference. The test will
fail with an obvious exception if my assumption is wrong.

But I think David is right. We will probably have to get rid of the
generics from assertThat altogether because the Java type system is
broken.

--Nat.
